title: Random expansions of trees with bounded height

sections.introduction:
When building a model for probabilistic inference we may not only want to take into account
properties and relations which are uncertain and described by (conditional) probabilities,
but also â€œbackground informationâ€ that is certain.
A common kind of background information is information about a hierarchical structure,
and such information can be described by a tree.
As an example of a tree that represents a hierarchical structure, consider a tree in which the children of the
root represent some communities, where the children of a community represent subcommunities, and
the children of a subcommunity represent individuals.
The height of this hierarchy, or tree, is 3 (or 4, depending on our conventions).
But the number of individuals in even the smallest subcommunity that we consider may be much larger than 3.
This article considers hierarchical background information represented by a tree such that
the height of the tree is very much smaller than the minimal number of children of a nonleaf of the tree. On top of the background information, represented by the example tree described above, we may consider information
that is given by (conditional) probabilities and is formally
represented by (parametrized) 0/1-valued (i.e. false/true-valued) random variables.
So we may have random variables (also viewed as atomic logical formulas) P1â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ƒ1ğ‘¥P_{1}(x), P2â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ƒ2ğ‘¥P_{2}(x), and P3â€‹(x)subscriptğ‘ƒ3ğ‘¥P_{3}(x),
representing some property that a community, subcommunity, respectively, individual, may have.
The probability that a subcommunity has the property P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} may (for example) depend on whether the community which it is part of has
property P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1}. Or alternatively, the probability that a community has P1subscriptğ‘ƒ1P_{1} may depend on the proportion of its
subcommunities that have P2subscriptğ‘ƒ2P_{2} (and/or the proportion of individuals in the community that have P3subscriptğ‘ƒ3P_{3}).
We may also have a random variable Râ€‹(x,y)ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦R(x,y), representing some relationship between objects, for example
the perception (good/bad) that xğ‘¥x has of yğ‘¦y. Now, for an individual xğ‘¥x, the probability that Râ€‹(x,y)ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦R(x,y) holds may
depend on properties of the (sub)community that xğ‘¥x belongs to and on properties of yğ‘¦y and/or its (sub)community;
it may also depend on whether xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y belong to the same (sub)community. Such uncertain, or probabilistic, information as exemplified above can be represented by a so-called (parametrized/lifted)
Probabilistic Graphical Model (PGM) based on the background knowledge represented by the tree.
(For introductions or surveys about PGMs, a tool in machine learning and statistical relational artifical intelligence, see for example
   .)
A (parametrized/lifted) PGM consists partly of a directed acyclic graph (DAG), the vertices of which are (parametrized/lifted)
random variables.
The arcs/arrows of the DAG describes the (in)dependencies between the random variables, by stipulating that
a random variable (a vertex of the DAG), say Rğ‘…R, is independent from all other vertices of the DAG, conditioned
on knowing the states (true/false) of the parents of Rğ‘…R in the DAG.
In the setup of this article a parametrized random variable will be identified with a relation symbol in the sense of formal logic.
So in the example above the vertex set of the DAG would be {P1,P2,P3,R}subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2subscriptğ‘ƒ3ğ‘…\{P_{1},P_{2},P_{3},R\},
where P1,P2,P3,Rsubscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2subscriptğ‘ƒ3ğ‘…P_{1},P_{2},P_{3},R are relation symbols, and its arcs would
describe the (conditional) (in)dependencies between the vertices. So far, nothing has been said about how to express (conditional) probabilities in a PGM and, indeed, there are
different ways of doing it.
It turns out that a general way of doing it is to use some sort of â€œprobability logicâ€,
as was first done (as far as we know) in the contex of PGMs by Jaeger in .
Here we will use a logic which we call Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*},
for probability logic with aggregation functions
(DefinitionÂ 3.4)
to describe (conditional) probabilities associated to the relation symbols of the DAG of a PGM. (The â€˜âˆ—*â€™ in Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*} just
indicates that it is a more general variant of earlier versions of Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Ağ‘ƒğ¿ğ´PLA considered
by Koponen and WeitkÃ¤mper in 1 2.)
The resulting type of PGM will be called a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-network
(DefinitionÂ 6.8). Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*} is a logic such that the (truth) values of its formulas can be any number in the unit interval   ,
so it is suitable for expressing probabilities.
Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*} achieves this partly by considering every câˆˆ ğ‘01c\in  as an atomic formula, and partly
by using aggregation functions which take finite sequences of reals in    as input and outputs a
real number in   .
An example of an aggregation function is the
arithmetic mean, or average, which returns the average of a finite sequence of reals in the unit interval.
So for example, if Rğ‘…R is a unary relation symbol then there is a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-formula (without free variables) such that
its value is the proportion of elements in the domain which satisfy Râ€‹(x)ğ‘…ğ‘¥R(x).
Since the aggregation functions maximum and minimum are available there is a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*} formula which
expresses that at least one (alternatively all) element in the domain satisfies Râ€‹(x)ğ‘…ğ‘¥R(x).
By using the aggregation functions maximum and minimum one can show that every query on finite structures
which can be expressed by a first-order formula can be expressed by a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-formula
(LemmaÂ 3.13).
Hence, Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*} subsumes first-order logic.
For a formula Ï†â€‹(x1,â€¦,xk)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\varphi(x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}) of Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}, finite structure ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} (with matching signature/vocabulary),
and a1,â€¦,akâˆˆAsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ´a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}\in A,
we let ğ’œâ€‹(Ï†â€‹(a1,â€¦,ak))ğ’œğœ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\mathcal{A}(\varphi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})) denote the value of Ï†â€‹(a1,â€¦,ak)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\varphi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}) in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}. The precise way that we will mathematically represent the kind of probabilistic (or uncertain) information described above
together with some background information, in the form of a tree, is as follows.
We let Î”Î”\Delta be a fixed positive integer and we let ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n}, where nğ‘›n is a positive integer, be a tree
with maximum height Î”Î”\Delta that represents the hierarchical background information.
Since we are interested in what happens for (arbitrarily) large trees where nonleaves have many children, we assume
that, for every positive integer kğ‘˜k, if nğ‘›n is large enough then every nonleaf in ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n} has at least kğ‘˜k children.
Each ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n} can be represented by a first-order Ï„ğœ\tau-structure where Ï„={E}ğœğ¸\tau=\{E\} and Eğ¸E is a binary
relation symbol of arity 2.
Then let Ïƒğœ\sigma be a finite relational signature that includes Ï„ğœ\tau.
In the example above we have Ïƒ={E,P1,P2,P3,R}ğœğ¸subscriptğ‘ƒ1subscriptğ‘ƒ2subscriptğ‘ƒ3ğ‘…\sigma=\{E,P_{1},P_{2},P_{3},R\}.
Then let ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} be the set of all expansions of ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n} to Ïƒğœ\sigma,
where we think of each such expansion ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} as a â€œpossible worldâ€, and let â„™nsubscriptâ„™ğ‘›\mathbb{P}_{n} be the probability distribution
on ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} induced by a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—â€‹(Ïƒ)ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´ğœPLA^{*}(\sigma)-network ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G} as defined in
DefinitionÂ 6.9 . So given a sequence ğ“=(ğ’¯n:nâˆˆâ„•+)\mathbf{T}=(\mathcal{T}_{n}:n\in\mathbb{N}^{+}) of trees (of the described kind) and a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—â€‹(Ïƒ)ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´ğœPLA^{*}(\sigma)-network ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G},
we have a precise mathematical setting of computing the probability of
a query (event) on ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} that can be expressed by a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-formula.
The probability of a query depends on both on the hierarchical information given by ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n} and by ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G}.
However, if we use the brute force way of computing the probability of a query, namely that
we compute the probability of every structure in ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} in which the query is true
and then add all such probabilities, then the time needed for the computation will be
exponential in the number of vertices of the
tree ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n}.
In other words, the brute force method of computing the probability of a query does not scale well to large trees ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n}.
This motivates the search for other methods of computing, or estimating, the probability of a query in the described context. In this article we identify certain conditions on the sequence of trees ğ“=(ğ’¯n:nâˆˆâ„•+)\mathbf{T}=(\mathcal{T}_{n}:n\in\mathbb{N}^{+})
(the stronger AssumptionÂ 6.3 and the milder AssumptionÂ 8.3), certain conditions on the Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—â€‹(Ïƒ)ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´ğœPLA^{*}(\sigma)-network ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G} used for defining a probability distribution on ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n},
roughly meaning that all aggregation functions used in the formulas associated to ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G} satisfy a continuity property, such that if Ï†â€‹(x1,â€¦,xk)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\varphi(x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}) (with free variables x1,â€¦,xksubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}) is a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—â€‹(Ïƒ)ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´ğœPLA^{*}(\sigma)-formula
in which all aggregation functions satisfy the continuity property, then there is a simpler, â€œclosure-basicâ€,
formula, say Ïˆâ€‹(x1,â€¦,xk)ğœ“subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜\psi(x_{1},\ldots,x_{k}), such that,
for all nğ‘›n and a1,â€¦,akâˆˆTnsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘›a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}\in T_{n}, the truth value of Ïˆâ€‹(a1,â€¦,ak)ğœ“subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\psi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}) in every structure ğ’œâˆˆğ–nğ’œsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathcal{A}\in\mathbf{W}_{n}
can be evaluated by using only (the fixed information defining) ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T}, ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G}, Ïˆğœ“\psi, and
the (bounded number of) ancestors of a1,â€¦,aksubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜a_{1},\ldots,a_{k} in ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n}, and for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0, if nğ‘›n is large enough, then, with probability at least 1âˆ’Îµ1ğœ€1-\varepsilon
(with the distribution induced by ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G}),
the values of Ï†â€‹(a1,â€¦,ak)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\varphi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}) and Ïˆâ€‹(a1,â€¦,ak)ğœ“subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\psi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}) differ by at most Îµğœ€\varepsilon.
(We will say that Ï†ğœ‘\varphi and Ïˆğœ“\psi are asymptotically equivalent.) This intuitively means that, for large enough nğ‘›n, with high probability the value of Ï†â€‹(a1,â€¦,ak)ğœ‘subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\varphi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k})
is approximated (with as good accuracy as we like) by the value of 
Ïˆâ€‹(a1,â€¦,ak)ğœ“subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜\psi(a_{1},\ldots,a_{k}) for all vertices a1,â€¦,aksubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜a_{1},\ldots,a_{k} in the tree ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n}.
Moreover, under the same conditions (1)â€“(3),
one can find such Ïˆğœ“\psi by using only Ï†ğœ‘\varphi, ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T} and ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G},
so the time needed to compute the approximation is independent of nğ‘›n, that is, of the size of the tree ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n}.
A corollary of the above result is that (under the same conditions)
we get a convergence law for Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-formulas, which of course has to be
suitably formulated in the context of many-valued formulas and
trees as â€œbackgroundâ€, or â€œbaseâ€, structures.
All three conditions (1)â€“(3) are necessary for the conclusions described to hold, as we will show. The main results, stated in SectionÂ 8.1, have the general form described above.
We first prove TheoremÂ 8.1.
Then we make some observations which allow us to easily obtain some corollaries which are variations of TheoremÂ 8.1.
The essence of these corollaries is (i) that if we consider stronger assumptions on the Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—â€‹(Ïƒ)ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´ğœPLA^{*}(\sigma)-network ğ”¾ğ”¾\mathbb{G}
(i.e. less general probability distributions), then we get results that apply to more queries,
and (ii) if we loosen the assumptions on the sequence of trees ğ“ğ“\mathbf{T} then we get results that apply to less,
but still interesting, queries. Related work.
Instead of bounding the height of the trees, as we do in this article, one could consider trees with a bound on the
number of children that vertices may have.
Such sequences of trees are covered by the (more general) context considered by Koponen in 0,
where probability distributions where defined by Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—â€‹(Ïƒ)ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´ğœPLA^{*}(\sigma)-networks and queries by Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-formulas.
Other work that we are aware of on logical convergence laws, and related issues, in the setting of
expansions of â€œbase structuresâ€ uses first-order logic
(or Lâˆ,Ï‰Ï‰superscriptsubscriptğ¿ğœ”ğœ”L_{\infty,\omega}^{\omega}) as the query language.
Baldwin  and Shelah  considered a base sequence where each â„¬nsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘›\mathcal{B}_{n} is a directed path of length nğ‘›n.
In both cases ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} consists of all expansions of â„¬nsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘›\mathcal{B}_{n} to a new binary relation symbol Rğ‘…R interpreted as an irreflexive
and symmetric relation.
In  the probability distribution on ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} is defined by letting an Râ€‹(x,y)ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦R(x,y) be true with probability
nâˆ’Î±superscriptğ‘›ğ›¼n^{-\alpha} for some irrational Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1), independently of whether it is true for other pairs.
In  the probability of Râ€‹(x,y)ğ‘…ğ‘¥ğ‘¦R(x,y) is dâˆ’Î±superscriptğ‘‘ğ›¼d^{-\alpha} where dğ‘‘d is the distance in â„¬nsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘›\mathcal{B}_{n} between xğ‘¥x and yğ‘¦y
and Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1) is irrational.
Lynch [25, CorollaryÂ 2.16] and later
Abu Zaid, Dawar, GrÃ¤del and Pakusa  and Dawar, GrÃ¤del and Hoelzel 0
considered the context where â„¬nsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘›\mathcal{B}_{n} is a product of finite cyclic groups and the probability distribution considered is the uniform one.
Ahlman and Koponen  considered base structures â„¬nsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘›\mathcal{B}_{n} with a (nicely behaved)
pregeometry and a probability distribution defined by a kind of stochastic block model where the â€œblocksâ€ correspond to subspaces.
Lynch 5 formulated a condition (kğ‘˜k-extendibility) that makes sense for base sequences ğğ\mathbf{B} in general
and which guarantees that a
convergence law holds for first-order logic and the uniform probability distribution. Besides this article and 0,
other studies that use a a PGM for generating a probability distribution and that prove some result about asymptic probabilities
do not consider background information in the form of a sequence of nontrivial base structures.
But in the context of no background information, when we let Ïƒğœ\sigma be a finite and relational signature,
ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} the set of all Ïƒğœ\sigma-structures with domain {1,â€¦,n}1â€¦ğ‘›\{1,\ldots,n\},
â„™nsubscriptâ„™ğ‘›\mathbb{P}_{n} a probability distribution induced by a PGM, there are some studies.
The most closely related to this one are
1 2 3 by Koponen and WeitkÃ¤mper and  by Jaeger.
But we also have 9 by Koponen, 8 9 by WeitkÃ¤mper, and 
by Cozman and Maua.
The first result about â€œasymptotic equivalenceâ€ between complex first-order formulas and simpler formulas was probably
given by Glebskii et. al. 3 and was used to prove the classical zero-one law for first-order logic,
also proved independently by somewhat different methods by Fagin 2.
Since the pioneering work in 3 and 2 a large number of studies on logical convergence laws and related
issues have been conducted in the fields of finite model theory and probabilistic combinatorics, but those studes consider
less flexible ways of generating probability distributions than PGMs (most often the uniform distribution). Organization.
SectionÂ 2 specifies some notation and terminology that will be used, as well as
a couple of probability theoretic results.
SectionÂ 3
defines the formal logic Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}, and some related notions, that will be used in PGMs and for defining queries (events).
SectionÂ 4 describes a general method (introduced in 3)
for â€œasymptotically eliminating aggregation functionsâ€.
SectionÂ 5
gives the necessary background about directed acyclic graphs and trees,
and some other notions related to trees, that will be used in the rest of the article.
SectionÂ 6
specifies the assumptions on the sequence of trees ğ“=(ğ’¯n:nâˆˆâ„•+)\mathbf{T}=(\mathcal{T}_{n}:n\in\mathbb{N}^{+}) that we make
and also explains why we make these assumptions.
It then defines the notion of a Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-network, which is the kind of PGM that we use, and how it induces a
probability distribution on the set ğ–nsubscriptğ–ğ‘›\mathbf{W}_{n} of all expansions to Ïƒğœ\sigma of ğ’¯nsubscriptğ’¯ğ‘›\mathcal{T}_{n}.
In sectionÂ 7 we prove technical results that imply that the assumptions of
TheoremÂ 4.8
in SectionÂ 4 are satisfied.
Therefore we can, in the last subsection of SectionÂ 7,
use TheoremÂ 4.8
and the results from earlier subsections of SectionÂ 7
to prove a result about â€œasymptotic elimination of aggregation functionsâ€.
In SectionÂ 8 we use induction on the height of the Pâ€‹Lâ€‹Aâˆ—ğ‘ƒğ¿superscriptğ´PLA^{*}-network
and the results from SectionÂ 7 to prove our main results.
